skills.name: Recognise the notation for parallel lines

explanations.A: The arrow symbol on a pair of lines indicates that the lines are parallel.
explanations.B: Perpendicular lines meet at right angles. Do these lines meet at right angles?
explanations.C: I think you have chosen the wrong term. Read the question carefully to see which lines we need to look at.
explanations.D: I think you are looking at the wrong line. The question is asking you about lines PQ and RS. What do you notice about these two lines?

explanations.A: I think you have chosen the wrong term. Read the question carefully to see which lines we need to look at.
explanations.B: Perpendicular lines meet at right angles. Do these lines meet at right angles?
explanations.C: The arrow symbol on a pair of lines indicates that the lines are parallel.
explanations.D: I think you are looking at the wrong line. The question is asking you about lines VW and XY. What do you notice about these two lines?

explanations.A: I think you are looking at the wrong lines. The question is asking you about line XY.
explanations.B: Perpendicular lines meet each other at right angles. Do these lines meet each other at right angles?
explanations.C: I think you have chosen the wrong term. Reconsider your knowledge of line notations
explanations.D: A transversal line passes through two lines at two distinct points.

explanations.A: I think you are looking at the wrong lines. The question is asking you about line JK.
explanations.B: A transversal line passes through two lines at two distinct points
explanations.C: I think you have chosen the wrong term. Reconsider your knowledge of line notations
explanations.D: Perpendicular lines meet each other at right angles. Do these lines meet each other at right angles?

explanations.A: I think you have identified the vertically opposite angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.
explanations.B: I think you have identified a corresponding angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.
explanations.C: I think you have identified a co-interior angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.
explanations.D: The alternate angle to QMY would be XNR. These 2 angles form a 'z shape' between the parallel lines.

explanations.C: I think you have identified a co-interior angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.
explanations.D: The alternate angle to MNS would be NMP. These 2 angles form a 'z shape' between the parallel lines.

explanations.A: I think you have identified the vertically opposite angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.
explanations.B: The corresponding angle to QMY would be SNY. These 2 angles form an 'f shape' between the parallel lines.
explanations.C: I think you have identified a co-interior angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.
explanations.D: I think you have identified an alternate angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.

explanations.A: I think you have identified the vertically opposite angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.
explanations.B: The corresponding angle to MNS would be QMX. These 2 angles form an 'f shape' between the parallel lines.
explanations.C: I think you have identified a co-interior angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.
explanations.D: I think you have identified an alternate angle. Reconsider your knowledge of angles on parallel lines.

explanations.A: I think you have identified the vertically opposite angle. Remember corresponding angles have the same relative position on the two parallel lines. Where would angle XMP be on line SR?
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you are looking at the wrong side of the transversal (the red line). Where would angle XMP be on line SR?
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember corresponding angles have the same relative position on the two parallel lines. Where would angle XMP be on line SR?
explanations.D: The corresponding angle to XMP would be XNR. These 2 angles form an 'f shape' between the parallel lines.

explanations.A: I think you have identified the vertically opposite angle. Remember corresponding angles have the same relative position on the two parallel lines. Where would angle XNR be on line QP?
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you are looking at the wrong side of the transversal (the red line). Where would angle XNR be on line QP?
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember corresponding angles have the same relative position on the two parallel lines. Where would angle XNR be on line QP?
explanations.D: The corresponding angle to XNR would be XMP. These 2 angles form an 'f shape' between the parallel lines.
